bibl.title: Annotated XML
bibl.note: The official XML 1.0 specification, with detailed explanatory and historical annotations by one of its editors, TimBray

bibl.title: AxKit
bibl.note: AxKit is an XML Application Server for Apache. It provides on-the-fly conversion from XML to any format, such as HTML, WAP or text using either W3C standard techniques, or flexible custom code. AxKit also uses a built-in Perl interpreter to provide some amazingly powerful techniques for XML transformation.

bibl.title: XML Catalog
bibl.note: The formal specification of the XML replacement of SGML catalogs.

bibl.title: A tutorial on character code issues
bibl.note: This useful tutorial by JukkaKorpela takes you through the morass of character encoding in an informal way.

bibl.title: Crimson
bibl.note: An XML parser from the Apache XML project
; (download).

bibl.title: CSS2
bibl.note: Cascading Style Sheets, version 2, W3C recommendation (May 1998) W3C.

bibl.title: DocBook
bibl.note: The DocBook DTDs, available in SGML and XML flavours, with many associated resources.

bibl.title: DOM
bibl.note: The Document Object Model (DOM) is the official W3C specification for a standard Application Programming Interface (API), defining how XML documents should be processed.
The spec has two levels. The Level 1 Specification (Version 1) appeared as a W3C Recommendation in 1 October, 1998 W3C..
The Level 2 Specification was confirmed as a W3C Recommendation in November 2000: .

bibl.title: eXist
bibl.note: eXist is a repository and retrieval engine for XML documents build on top of an relational database (MySQL or Oracle). It provides structured retrieval of arbitrary xml documents with support for fulltext search, based on traditional rdbms.

(documentation);
(software).

bibl.title: Emacs
bibl.note:
Gnu Emacs, the world's favourite text editor, can easily edit and validate XML documents. We include here a complete working setup for XML and TEI work, in ; Windows users can run it directly from the CD - just run . Unix/Linux users need to add the following to their .emacs file:
(setq homedir "/xmlcd/tei-emacs") (add-to-list 'load-path (concat homedir "/elisp")) (load-library "tei-emacs-init")
if /xmlcd is where you copied the tei-emacs directory to.

The setup includes LennartStaflin's PSGML emacs package for editing XML and SGML, and TonyGraham's XSLIDE package for editing XSL. BobDuCharme has published online a chapter of his SGML book which explains how to write and modify SGML files using Emacs and PSGML. These 100 pages called "Editing SGML documents with the Emacs text editor" are an excellent tutorial to learn and understand PSGML thoroughly. It is at .

This enhanced Emacs distribution is also available as a single executable, which you can use to install the system on any Windows 95, 98, ME, NT, or 2000 machine. You don't even need to copy it off the CD, just run .

bibl.title: EXSLT
bibl.note: EXSLT is an open community initiative to standardise and document extensions to XSLT. The extensions are broken down into a number of modules, currently Common, Math, Sets and Functions.

bibl.title: FOP
bibl.note: FOP is an engine from the Apache XML Group for converting the Formatting Objects specified by XSL to printable form (PDF). It is work in progress, and does not yet implement the full specification, but it is very useable.

bibl.title: JD XSLT
bibl.note: An XSLT processor by JohannesDöbler implementing the proposed XSLT 1.1. You will also need an XML parser (it defaults to Crimson).

bibl.title: JING: A Relax NG validator
bibl.note: An implementation in Java of , by James Clark.

note.q: A LiveDTD is a Document Type Definition converted into a hypertext document. It is also a perl program (livedtd.pl) that performs that conversion. It parses the DTD files and generates a copy with HTML markup inserted. The result is the exact same text of the original DTD, but with live links that let you navigate through the DTD. Click on a name, and you are transported to where that name is declared in the DTD. Both elements and parameter entities are hot linked

bibl.title: LTG XML tools
bibl.note: Tools from Edinburgh University's Language Technology Group for processing arbitrary XML documents, including sggrep (an XML-aware version of the popular grep utility) and others.

bibl.title: Lampeter Corpus
bibl.note: A corpus of 120 Early Modern English tracts marked up in XML, indexed and searchable with SARA (the SGML-Aware Retrieval Application developed at Oxford for the British National Corpus).
On the CD in .

bibl.title: Libxslt and Libxml
bibl.note: Libxslt is a C implementation of XSLT by DanielVeillard. It is based on libxml (the Gnome XML library) for XML parsing, tree manipulation and XPath support. It is written in plain C, making as few assumptions as possible, and sticking closely to ANSI C/POSIX for easy embedding. This library is released under the GNU LGPL and a derivative of the W3C IPR. Though not designed primarily with performances in mind, libxslt seems to be a relatively fast processor.

bibl.title: MS IE5 XML
bibl.note: Early versions of Microsoft's Internet Explorer version 5 were only partially XML aware. The current release update () to the popular web browser extends its abilities considerably, most notably in the area of conformance to the current XSLT specification. There has been a lot of confusion about this, so the Unofficial MSXML XSLT FAQ by JoshuaAllen will prove very helpful, at .

There are two updates. The most recent is MSXML4, at . Just run the installer. If that causes problems, the older MSXML3 may be more stable. Installing this one is in two parts; first you have to get it on your system, and then make it the default. The update installer itself is . If that complains that your Microsoft installer is too old, here is a copy of a recent copy for Windows 9X or Windows NT/2000 which may help. To get the XML parser software actually working, you will need the program, documented at . Additional documentation details, the SDK, and other tools: .
There is a lot of useful discussion on this topic at .

bibl.title: MathML
bibl.note: MathML is an XML document type definition for the representation of mathematics, now supported by the W3C. It covers most aspects of mathematical typesetting and representation.

bibl.title: OpenJade
bibl.note: Jade is a processor for the Document Style and Semantics Specification Language (DSSSL), a precursor of the XSLT language, written by JamesClark, and now supported by the OpenJade group.

(documentation);
(software).

bibl.title: Oxford Text Archive
bibl.note:
The Oxford Text Archive has a very large archive of SGML and XML literary and linguistic texts, from which we have selected a few titles here, to demonstrate how the TEI Guidelines can be used in practice:
Charles Dickens A Christmas Carol (with illustrations by J Leech) in .
John Milton's Paradise Lost in .
John Webster's The Duchess of Malfi in .
Thomas Hardy's A Pair of Blue Eyes in .

bibl.title: PassiveTeX
bibl.note: PassiveTex is a system developed by SebastianRahtz for printing XSL formatting objects, using the TeX document processing system

bibl.title: Protestant Cemetery
bibl.note: A demonstration database of archaeological records, documenting the gravestones in the Protestant Cemetery at Rome, marked up in XML.
On the CD in ; a demonstration catalogue derived from the XML is on the CD in .

bibl.title: RDF
bibl.note: Resource Description Framework (RDF) is a W3C specification for the high level representation of metadata, currently expressed as an XML DTD.

bibl.title: RefDB
bibl.note: RefDB is a reference database and bibliography tool for DocBook SGML/XML and LaTeX/BibTeX documents. It allows users to share databases over a network. It is lightweight and portable to basically all platforms with a decent C compiler. It is written by MarcusHoenicka

bibl.title: Relax NG: A schema language for XML
bibl.note: The key features of Relax NG are that it is simple, easy to learn, uses XML syntax, does not change the information set of an XML document, supports XML namespaces, treats attributes uniformly with elements so far as possible, has unrestricted support for unordered content, has unrestricted support for mixed content, has a solid theoretical basis, and can partner with a separate datatyping language (such W3C XML Schema Datatypes). A tutorial is available at
Trial Relax NG schemas for the TEI are available at .

bibl.title: RXP
bibl.note: A small and very fast XML parser developed by RichardTobin, and available for Windows or Unix.

bibl.title: SAX
bibl.note: SAX is a simple, event-driven, applications programming interface for XML developed by DavidMegginson.

bibl.title: SAXON
bibl.note: SAXON is a fast, lightweight, and 100% conformant XSLT processor developed by MichaelKay; it is written in Java, so it runs anywhere, and there is also a Windows .exe file for easy use. It is packaged with a copy of Aelfred, a small and fast XML parser.
, with downloads from ,

bibl.title: SGML setup for Windows
bibl.note: MarcusHoenicka has written a useful brief tutorial how to set up a free SGML editing and publishing system for Windows NT.

bibl.title: Schema
bibl.note: This W3C specification defines a new schema language, designed to replace the DTD language inherited by XML from SGML. Tools for processing Schema language are starting to appear.

bibl.title: SP
bibl.note: SP is the most widely used SGML toolkit. Originally developed by JamesClark, it includes a powerful parser, capable of processing both SGML and XML documents, and a suite of utilities for normalising SGML, converting it to XML, etc.

bibl.title: SVG
bibl.note: The Standard Vector Graphics language is a W3C standard for the representation of vector graphics using XML.

bibl.title: Schematron
bibl.note: Schematron is an XSL-based processor, which can be used to check the semantics of XML documents, developed by RickJelliffe.

bibl.title: Tidy
bibl.note: Tidy is a utility developed by DaveRaggett which can be used to clean up HTML files, and also to convert them to XML.

bibl.title: Transcoding
bibl.note: Notes on Unicode Transcoders, written by RickJelliffe. This is essential reading for people interested in non-Latin scripts.

bibl.title: Unicode entity mappings
bibl.note: A set of entity files which map the ISO entity sets to their Unicode equivalent; there is also a detailed XML document () which provides detailed mapping information for much of the western language and symbol part of Unicode.

bibl.title: XHTML
bibl.note: This W3C Recommendation specifies the reformulation of HTML 4 as an XML DTD.

bibl.title: XLINK
bibl.note: This W3C Proposal specifies a range of standardized hyperlinking functionalities in XML.

bibl.title: Xindice
bibl.note: Apache Xindice is a database designed from the ground up to store XML data or what is more commonly referred to as a native XML database.

bibl.title: XML Quick Reference
bibl.note: This is a handy reference card for the essential details of XML made available by Mulberry Technologies.

bibl.title: XPath
bibl.note: This W3C Recommendation documents the XML Path Language (XPath), Version 1.0, which is used to address arbitrary parts of an XML document, and underlies an increasingly large number of XML retrieval applications.

(XML)
(HTML).

bibl.title: XSL (Formatting Objects)
bibl.note: This W3C Recommendation documents the Extensible Stylesheet Language (XSL), which describes a standard language for formatting XML documents. It is partially implemented by several suppliers (see PassiveTeX and FOP). There is a useful instroduction by DavidPawson at .
For the full specification, see .

bibl.title: XSL Tutorials and FAQ
bibl.note:
There are plenty of useful XSL tutorial materials around:
A handy set of XSL Frequently Asked Questions edited by DavidPawson is at .
An extensive tutorial covering all of the XSLT specification, by KenHolman can be sampled at , and purchased online at reasonable rates.
A collection of source files demonstrating how to use XSLT, taken from MichaelKay's XSLT Programmers' Reference: .
The XSLT Quick Reference is a reference card for the essential details of XSLT made available by Mulberry Technologies; .
A detailed tutorial on XSLT is an extract from Rusty ElliotteHarold's XML Bible, generously made freely available as a sampler by its author and publisher at .
JeniTennison maintains a fine web site about good practice and experience in XSLT programming at (also needs , , , and )

bibl.title: XSL IDE
bibl.note: An XSL mode for Emacs, by TonyGraham.

bibl.title: XSLT
bibl.note: This W3C Recommendation documents the XSL Transformation Language (XSLT), Version 1.0

(XML)
(HTML). A draft release of version 1.1 is also available for comment at .

bibl.title: XT
bibl.note: XT is a fast and efficient XSLT processor developed by JamesClark available for Windows or Unix. XP is Clark's XML parser which can be used with XT.
